bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to the Earl of Orkney, April 11, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to the Earl of Orkney, the titular governor of Virginia, April 11, 1729, concerning the situation in the colony over his son Charles's succeeding his brother Robert as naval officer of the Rappahannock and efforts of the Grymes family to obtain the post for Charles Grymes.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to the Earl of Orkney, April 11, 1729

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Apl. 11th: 1729
The Rt: Honble. George
Earl of Orkney——

div1.p:
This is the first Opportunity I have had since
the rect. of your Lordships kind favour of the 7th day of Novr. last wherein it is no
Small pleasure to me to find yor. Lordship satisfied of my Integrity in rela-
tion to yor Lordships Salary.

I Esteem my self highly Indebted to your LdShip for yor
oblidgeing recommendation to our Govr. in behalf of my Son Charles's
Succeeding to the Naval Office of this river upon the removal of his Brother Robert
he is removed and the Govr. is pleased this far to Continue the Place to him, but
does not think it proper either to give a Deputation to h[is br]other Charles
or to give him a Commission for the Place Alledge[ing . . .]ized into
a promise at his first coming in to Colonel Chas: Grimes Brother to or. recr. Genl.
to give him the Place when when he Should take it away from my sont Robert, Chs.
Grimes is now put into the Collectors Place of this river if he can hold it, the Govr.
would be altogether discharged from his word but if another be put in England
then I can hardly Say how it will go. Altho the Govr. hath bin so kind to [illegible] give
me his repeated promise word that he will not turn out my Son Robert, but that the
Place Shall remain in my family, As long as it Shall Lye in his power to
Continue it With a due regard to his word Thus I have Presumed to acquaint
your Ld.Ship with the naked truth of this Story, whether your LdShip will think
it proper to Concern yor.Self any further in this matter I must Submit to your
goodness Desireing however a Continuance of yor. remembrance when your Ld.Ship
Shall think fitt to give your self the trouble I am in all Duty
div1.closer:
My Lord
Yor. Lordships
Most Obedient
Most Obliged
& most humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence when writing to persons abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.
